title: George Thomson (rugby)
text:
George Thomas Thomson (26 November 1856 – 31 October 1899) was an English <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> footballer who played in the 1870s and 1880s. He played at representative level for <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a>, and <a href="Yorkshire%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Yorkshire</a>, and at club level for <a href="Halifax%20R.L.F.C.">Halifax</a>, in the <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Forwards">forwards</a>, e.g. <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Front%20row">front row</a>, <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Locks">lock</a>, or <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%23Back%20row">back row</a>. Prior to Tuesday 27 August 1895, Halifax was a <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> club.
Background.
George Thomson was born in <a href="Skircoat%20Green">Skircoat</a>, <a href="Halifax%2C%20West%20Yorkshire">Halifax</a>, <a href="West%20Riding%20of%20Yorkshire">West Riding of Yorkshire</a>, and he died in <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a>, Australia.
Playing career.
International honours.
George Thomson won caps for <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> while at Halifax in 1878 against Scotland, in 1882 against Ireland, Scotland, and Wales, in 1883 against Ireland, and Scotland, in 1884 against Ireland, and Scotland, and in 1885 against Ireland.
In the early years of rugby football the "goal" was to score goals, and a <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">try</a> had zero value, but it provided the opportunity to "try" at goal, and "<a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">convert</a>" the try to a goal with an unopposed kick at the goal posts. The point values of both the try and goal have varied over time, and in the early years footballers could "score" a try, without scoring any points.
Honoured at Halifax RLFC.
George Thomson is a Halifax RLFC Hall of Fame inductee.
